title: HTTP Request Smuggling
content:
When malformed or abnormal HTTP requests are interpreted by one or more entities in the data flow between the user and the web server, such as a proxy or firewall, they can be interpreted inconsistently, allowing the attacker to "smuggle" a request to one device without the other device being aware of it.
publishers.basicattentiontoken.org is vulnerable to CL TE ( Front end server uses Content-Length , Back-end Server uses Transfer-encoding ) HTTP request smuggling attack.

Any suggestions or improvement in reports are welcome as this is my first report.
Impact
It is possible to smuggle the request and disrupt the user experience. Session Hijacking, Privilege Escalation and cache poisoning can be the impact of this vulnerability as well.
As unauthenticated testing is performed the exact impact of the vulnerability cannot be predicted.
For more information about the vulnerability please refer :
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/444.html ;
https://capec.mitre.org/data/definitions/33.html
steps: Prepare a malformed HTTP request with both 'Content-Length' and 'Transfer-Encoding' headers, containing a hidden request.
Send the request to the target server (publishers.basicattentiontoken.org) using a tool like Burp Suite Turbo Intruder.
vuln_description: The vulnerability is a HTTP Request Smuggling attack where malformed requests are interpreted inconsistently by different components (front-end and back-end servers), allowing an attacker to smuggle a request to one component without the other being aware. This can lead to session hijacking, privilege escalation, or cache poisoning.
reason: The attack requires knowledge of HTTP protocol nuances and the specific behavior of the target's front-end and back-end servers. However, once the inconsistency in header handling is identified, crafting the exploit is relatively straightforward.
